title: 113_hr4756
content: The "Bullying Redress and Verified Enforcement Act" or the "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include reporting requirements on bullying. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying, mandating local educational agencies to report bullying incidents within 7 business days. The "BRAVE Act" requires local educational agencies to report bullying incidents within 7 business days, including details on the bullying's motivation and the response by agency employees. The "BRAVE Act" mandates local educational agencies to report bullying incidents promptly, but employees are not required to report if a student requests confidentiality. Agencies must designate a contact person to receive bullying reports. The designated individual must inform all employees of the local educational agency about reported acts of bullying within 60 days, excluding any student's personal information. Additionally, quarterly reports on bullying incidents must be made publicly available. The local educational agency must publish quarterly reports summarizing reported bullying incidents and employee responses, excluding any student's personal information. The local educational agency must publish quarterly reports summarizing bullying incidents and employee responses, excluding student personal information, and informing the public of the right to file a complaint. Each local educational agency must annually review bullying policies for schools served, excluding personally identifiable student information. Local agencies receiving funds under this Act must certify compliance with the Secretary. Local educational agencies must annually certify compliance with bullying policies to the Secretary and submit the 4 most recent quarterly reports. The Assistant Secretary of the Office of Civil Rights must establish a procedure for receiving complaints from students or parents. The Department of Education must establish a procedure for complaints related to non-compliance with bullying policies, to be published on their website. The Assistant Secretary will investigate complaints received to determine any violations. The Assistant Secretary will investigate complaints of non-compliance with bullying policies and take action against local educational agencies found to have failed to comply. This may include withholding funds and issuing complaints to compel compliance. The Assistant Secretary can take action against non-compliant local educational agencies by issuing complaints, entering into compliance agreements, or issuing cease and desist orders, similar to actions authorized under the General Education Provisions Act. The Assistant Secretary can take actions under sections 455, 456, and 457 of the General Education Provisions Act to address complaints, making information about the complaint publicly available on the Department of Education's website within 60 days. This information includes details about any protected characteristics involved in the bullying incident. The definition of bullying in this section includes severe, pervasive, or persistent acts by one student or a group towards another student based on a protected characteristic. Personal information of students is excluded. The definition of bullying in this section includes harmful actions towards another student based on a protected characteristic, causing harm or concern for their well-being or causing them to avoid school services or activities. Protected characteristics include race, color, sex, religion, national origin, disability, gender, gender identity, and sexual orientation.
